itemListElement.description: SME - Environmental studies, research

CARICOOS is the Caribbean Coastal Ocean Observing System. This effort, funded by the NOAA IOOS office http://ioos.noaa.gov/, is one of eleven coastal observing systems and regional associations which along with federal agencies constitute the national coastal component of the US Integrated Ocean Observing System. For more information on the regional associations, please visit http://www.ioosassociation.org This web page brings together coastal ocean data and forecasts from a variety of sources including satellites, ocean instruments and numerical models to give the user an integrated view of past, present and forecasted ocean conditions in the US Caribbean region. Data are provided online by a number of organizations including NOAA, NASA, ONR Universities, and others to whom credit is given. Data and graphics, other than NOAA National Weather Service products, are presented as experimental products.

NIOZ is the National Oceanographic Institution of the Netherlands, and belongs to the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO). NIOZ carries out fundamental research in wetlands, shallow coastal seas, as well as in the open ocean, in the four basic disciplines of oceanography (physics, chemistry, biology and geology). The institute plays a facilitating and coordinating role within Dutch oceanographic research, acts as an incubator of scientific talent, knowledge and technology, and facilitates marine research collaboration and education at the national, European and international level.

The Gulf and Caribbean Fisheries Institute (GCFI) was founded in 1947 to promote the exchange of current information on the use and management of marine resources in the Gulf and Caribbean region. From its beginning, GCFI has endeavored to involve scientific, governmental, and commercial sectors to provide a broad perspective on relevant issues, and to encourage dialogue among groups that often operate in relative isolation from one another.
Environmental and Coastal Engineering and Design Office

Consortium of 20 social, natural and physical science researchers from University of Southampton (Lead), University of Ghana, University of West Indies and University of York researching "Teleconnected SARgassum risks across the Atlantic: building capacity for TRansformational Adaptation in the Caribbean and West Africa". We are funded by the ESRC GCRF Equitable Resilience Fund. Project runs for 36 months from Nov 2019-Oct 2022.

Science Serving Florida’s Coast
Florida Sea Grant is a university-based program that supports research, education and extension to conserve coastal resources and enhance economic opportunities for the people of Florida.

We are an integral part of the Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences at the University of Florida, one of the nation’s leading Land Grant universities. 

Our vision and mission
Florida Sea Grant envisions a future where people use our coastal and marine resources in ways that capture the economic and social benefits they offer, while preserving their quality and abundance for future generations.

Florida Sea Grant’s mission is to support integrated research, education and extension to conserve coastal resources and enhance economic opportunities for the people of Florida.
Higher Education Research University

CANARI is a non-profit technical institute with thirty years’ experience of research, policy influence and capacity building for participatory natural resource governance in the Caribbean. CANARI’s mission is promoting and facilitating equitable participation and effective collaboration in the management of natural resources critical to development in the Caribbean islands, so that people will have a better quality of life and natural resources will be conserved, through action learning and research, capacity building, communication and fostering partnerships. CANARI facilitates and promotes participatory approaches to natural resource governance to conserve biodiversity, enhance ecosystem goods and services, and enhance the livelihoods and wellbeing of the poor in the Caribbean. This is done through multidisciplinary research, capacity building, partnerships, communication and advocacy with a the full range of stakeholders in the Caribbean, inclusive of overseas territories.
CNAP is part of the Department of Biology at the University of York (United Kingdom).
Federal Research and Post Graduate Institution

Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS) is a global company and pioneer provider of monitoring and surveillance solutions for the Earth, created in 1986.  Our mission is  to  create innovative  space-based  solutions  to understand and protect our planet and to manage its resources sustainably. CLS employs 720 people at our headquarters in Toulouse (France) and in 25 other sites around the world. The company works in five strategic markets:  sustainable fisheries management,  environmental  monitoring,  maritime surveillance, fleet management, and energy & mining.

Sargassum Research Group at INTEC
Small group of researchers across multiple disicplines have been working on mitigation of algal blooms on coastal areas in teh Dominican Republic. We focus on minimizing the imapct algal blooms have on coastal communities and ecosystems.  We promote the improvement of collection systems and management, and try to minimize the economical burden coastal communities withstand from alagal bloom events.

CERMES is a department within the Faculty of Science and Technology of the University of the West Indies, Cave Hill Campus. Established in 1986, CERMES was created in response to the Caribbean’s need for a multidisciplinary programme that incorporated environmental issues into sustainable development. Hence, CERMES’ Mission: To make a significant contribution to sustainable development in the Caribbean region. 
Teaching and learning are central to CERMES and we are well known for our MSc programme in Natural Resource and Environmental Management, with three management specialisations: Coastal and Marine Resources, Climate Change, and Water Resources. CERMES also offers MPhil and PhD research degrees in the broad areas of Environmental Studies and Natural Resource Management. Research, outreach and consultancy are also key functions of CERMES. We have a proud history of research collaborations with numerous regional and international partners .

CONABIO has the mission of promoting, coordinating, supporting and carrying out activities aimed at the knowledge of biological diversity, as well as its conservation and sustainable use for the benefit of society. It was conceived as an applied research organization, promoter of basic research, that compiles and generates information on biodiversity, develops human capacities in the area of biodiversity informatics, and is a public source of information and knowledge accessible to all of society.
 
It is an institution that generates intelligence on our natural capital; it serves as a bridge between the academy, the government and society; promotes that the conservation and management of biodiversity is based on actions carried out by the local population, which should be a central actor in this process.

Transport and mixing in the ocean
Lagrangian coherent structures
Markov chains
Nonlinear dynamics

The Fisheries Oceanography and Ecology Lab is led by Dr. Frank Hernandez (Associate Professor, Division of Coastal Sciences, University of Southern Mississippi). Our research focus is fisheries oceanography, with an emphasis on marine fish early life stages (eggs, larvae and juveniles). Specific interests include the impacts of climate variability and natural and anthropogenic disturbances on the biological and physical processes that influence fish recruitment, habitat associations, and the ecology of early life stages.

Develop and support research, training and outreach activities for the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez focused in marine sciences, coastal oceanography, GIS and remote sensing. Developer of GIS and remote sensing web/mobile mapping applications to support human/environmental resources data collection.

Founded in 1834, DESMI is the first choice in pumping systems and contention booms, in response to marine oil spills.  The DESMI Seaweed  Division has created solutions for sargassum contention and in-water removal.  Our team is built of technician specialists, engineers and oceanographers to create the best environmental technology.  Our products are designed to meet strict international environmental standards and manufactured with the best materials.

Specto Natura Ltd. a Cambridge, UK-based Earth Observation (EO) consultancy. SN enables and advises its clients on the delivery of useful, accurate and reliable environmental information from remote sensing / EO data by working at the interface between users, service providers and technology developers.
